Although I think of the '60s in many ways as the era of the Kennedys and Martin Luther King and the civil-rights movement, as we should, it was also the era of Nixon, who was one of the most fascinating and enigmatic and in many ways scary figures in American political history.
I think he really was the dominant political figure of the '50s and '60s.
He embodied something about America, but something that's scary about America.
And that is that we love winners.
We don't ask how they won, unless somebody, usually a journalist, rubs our nose in it.
Then we say we had no idea he was taking steroids or whatever the other thing might have been.
And then we turn, in a fury, on this person.
But we don't ask.
We don't inquire how people win.
We love that we win.
And Nixon was a guy who knew how to win.
He embodied that scary aspect of America.
Why this period of history?
You mentioned a certain interest or fascination with Richard Nixon.
Was it that that drove you, or were you interested in placing a story in this period of time?
Was it Nixon or Mona Visi or just a fascination with the '50s and '60s?
I think that's a great question, and I think you have to understand the 1960s to understand modern America.

So many of the battles we still fight today we were fighting then - all sorts of traditional understandings about the role of women, about the role of black people - a lot of different things were overturned in that time.
And there was something else they had in the '60s.

There's something we take as a given in politics that Nixon actually invented, and that's the idea that politics, especially for national elections, divided between these hard-working, middle-class traditionalists on this side and these scary liberals on the other side.
That was a new way of dividing the electorate, in 1968 when Nixon mapped it out.
And every year, the candidates, the media, everybody takes that as a starting point.
That was Nixon's invention as a way of breaking up the Democratic, solid South, but it was a new kind of politics.
That's one of the many, many ways in which the 1960s foreshadow the current era.

I liked your vision of a pastel.
That is - I mean it as a light touch, but the touch is always there.

So I want the reader to become lost in the story, but at the same time to every now and then notice those light brush strokes where I try to illuminate a little piece of the issue of race in America without ever wanting to write a message book.
I'm not trying to teach or hit the reader over the head.
I'm trying to write an entertainment, but I have a few light brush strokes in there, and I suppose I always will.
